awd_titl_txt: Surface and Bulk Properties of Layered Transition-Metal Compounds: Manifestations of Broken Symmetry
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL ABSRTACT
This award from the Condensed Matter Physics Program of the Division of Materials Research supports experimental condensed-matter physics research on new class of materials that are relevant to future energy applications and advanced electronic devices.  This class of materials, complex transition metal compounds, exhibit new physical properties that cannot be understood with traditional approaches.  The complementary expertise of two scientists, one on surface (one atomic layer) and the other on bulk, will allow us to explore the fundamental physics underlying the emergent phenomena seen in both surface and bulk.  Creating a surface allows this team to explore the manifestations of broken symmetry on this new class of materials. Our ultimate goal is to address one of the grand challenges of materials science: how do complex phenomena emerge from simple ingredients?  Through combined effort of two scientists, this research project offers an ideal training ground for undergraduates, graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and visiting scholars, exposing them in frontier scientific research.  In particular, Ph.D. students, supported through this project, will have hands-on experience in state-of-the-art instrumentation, and be trained for careers either in academia, national laboratories, or industries.

TECHNICAL ABSRTACT
This research project, supported by Condensed Matter Physics Program of the Division of Materials Research is designed to study the surface and bulk physical properties of newly discovered transition-metal layered compounds.  This class of materials exhibit strong coupling between charge, spin, lattice and orbital.  Their physical properties are extremely susceptible to a subtle change either internally (chemical doping), or externally such as magnetic field or pressure.  Creating a surface by cleaving these layer-materials is an ideal way to distort the delicate balance in the bulk, and explore the manifestations of broken symmetry. The complementary expertise of two scientists, one on surface and the other on bulk, will allow us to explore the fundamental physics underlying the emergent phenomena in this class of materials.  The ultimate goal is to address one of the grand challenges of materials science: how do complex phenomena emerge from simple ingredients?  Through combined effort of two scientists, this research project offers an ideal training ground for undergraduates, graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and visiting scholars, exposing them in frontier scientific research.  In particular, Ph.D. students, supported through this project, will have hands-on experience in state-of-the-art instrumentation, and be trained for careers either in academia, national laboratories, or industries. Both of the principal investigators have been hosting students from Louisiana high schools, LSU through the "Chancellor's Future Leaders in Research" program, and NSF supported REU program.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Louisiana State University & Agricultural and Mechanical College

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Introduction: In the past year of this NSF grant, we have published 4 refereed articles [1-4], two under review [5-6], and two to be submitted [7-8]. We have also delivered 2 invited talks. In 2021, Jin received the LSU Senior Rainmaker Award.

 1.  Emergent spin glass behavior created by self-assembled antiferromagnetic NiO columns in ferrimagnetic NiFe2O4 (NFO) via the floating-zone technique [1]: We have created an interfacial spin glass state by self-assembling single crystalline NiO micro columns in the spinel NiFe2O4 matrix (Figs. 1(a-d)). The atomically-sharp interfaces (Figs. 1(e-f)) between them result in spin disorder and/or frustration, which enters the spin glass state below 28 K (Figs. 1(g-i)). Our work illustrates that the creation of magnetically frustrated interface requires perfectly matched atomic structure but broken translational and magnetic symmetries at the interface. A paper describing this work is published in Applied Materials and Interfaces [1], which is partially supported by this grant.

2.  Mn-induced spin glass behavior in metallic Ir3Sn7-xMnx [2]: By introducing Mn (~10%) into A non-magnetic Ir3Sn7, two interesting features are observed: (1) Mn occupies the Sn2 site (Fig. 2(a)), and (2) Mn moment induces spin glass behavior (Figs. 2(b-c)).  This work will be published in J. Physics: Condensed Matter [2], which is partially supported by this grant.

3.  Bulk and surface phase diagrams for Sr3(Ru1-xMnx)2O7  [5-6]: With the ability of growing single crystals with 0 ≤ x ≤ 1.0, we have constructed a complete phase diagram for bulk Sr3(Ru1-xMnx)2O7 (Fig. 3(a)). In addition to the known metal-insulator transition (MIT) (metallic at T > TMIT and insulating at T < TMIT), the magnetic susceptibility shows a characteristic peak at TM with four different ground states (Regions III - VI). Detailed description of this work is included in Ref. [6], which is partially supported by this grant.

We have also found that the surface phase diagram (Fig. 3(b)) is dramatically different from its counter bulk. For 0 ≤ x ≤ 0.23, both the zero-bias conductance (dI/dV) measured by scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) and Fano parameter (q) obtained from electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) exhibit the extreme at xc ~ 0.16. This indicates that the surface is metallic, despite the fact that the bulk is insulating. We consider that the physical properties Sr3(Ru1-xMnx)2O7 are dictated by the local crystal structure: both the tilt angle of (Ru/Mn)O6 and the in-plane bonding length (Ru/Mn-O3) reveal extreme at xc as well. The result is summarized in the manuscript Ref. [5], which is supported by this grant.

Broader Impact: This funding was supporting two (2) graduate students (Joanna Blawat and Yifang Yang) and one (1) undergraduate researcher (Alston Rivera). The PI has given a number of lectures including invited talks at conferences and university colloquiums. A graduate student (Joanna Blawat) gave a contributed talk at the APS meeting 2021.

References:

1.        Roshan Nepal, Zhen Wang, Samuel Dai, Mohammad Saghayezhian, Yimei Zhu, E. W. Plummer, Rongying Jin, ?Emergent spin glass behavior created by self-assembled antiferromagnetic NiO columns in ferromagnetic NiFe2O4?, Applied Materials and Interfaces 12, 38788 (2020).

2.        Smita Speer, M. Marshall, H. Chang, R. Nepal, J. Blawat, R. Chapai, X. Gui, W. Xie, R. Jin, ?Structural and Physical Properties of Ir3Sn7-xMnx Single Crystals?, J. Phys.: Cond. Mater. 33, 135701 (2021).

3.        Y. Sharma, A. Mazza, B. L. Musico, R. K. Nepal, Rongying Jin, A. V. Ievlev, L. Collins, Z. Gai, E. Skoropata, A. Chen, M. Brahlek, V. Keppens, T. Zac Ward, ?Magnetism in Highly-Insulating Configurationally Complex Single Crystal Spinel Films?, Applied Mat. & Interfaces 13, 17971 (2021).

4.        Tochukwu Ofoegbuna, B. Peterson, Natalia da Silva Moura, R. K. Nepal, Orhan Kizikaya, Carsyn Smith, Rongying Jin, Craig Plaisance, John Flake, James Dorman, ?Modifying Metastable Sr1-xBO3-d (B = Nb, Ta, Mo) Perovskites for Electrode Materials?, Applied Mat. & Interfaces 13, 25 (2021).

5.        Yifan Yang, Mingming Fu, Qiang Zou, Zheng Gai, Biao Hu, Weiwei Xie, T. Albrecht-Schoenzart, Jiandi Zhang, Rongying Jin, E. W. Plummer, ?Surface Critical Point Determined by Octahedral Tilt in Sr3(Ru1-xMnx)2O7?, J. Electron Spectroscopy (under review).

6.        R. Nepal, L. Xing, A. Meingast, Rongying Jin, ?Mn-induced multiple magnetic ground states in Sr3(Ru1-xMnx)2O7?, Phys. Rev. Research (under review).

7.        Z. Wang, G. Cao, R. Jin, Y. Zhu, E. W. Plummer, ?Investigation of structure transition of IrTe2 by STEM? (to be submitted).

8.        Yifan Yang, M. Fu, Q. Zou, Z. Gai, B. Hu, W. Xie, J. Zhang, R. Jin, E. W. Plummer, ?Non-magnetic metallic surface on bulk antiferromagnetic insulator Sr3(Ru0.84Mn0.16)2O7? (to be submitted).

Modified by: Rongying Jin
